title: 114_hr3476
content: SHORT TITLE; FINDINGS. The Act is titled the "Prevent a Government Shutdown Act of 2015" and discusses the Budget Control Act of 2011, which set spending caps and required deficit reduction through negotiations or sequestration. Despite unsuccessful negotiations, a two-year agreement was reached in 2014 and 2015 to increase spending levels. A similar agreement is now needed to avoid deep cuts. The Budget Control Act of 2011 set spending caps and required deficit reduction through negotiations or sequestration. A two-year agreement in 2014 and 2015 increased spending levels to avoid deep cuts. Senator John McCain and Representative Mac Thornberry criticized defense spending cuts under sequestration, impacting capabilities, readiness, and morale of armed forces. NDD United highlighted the negative effects of self-imposed cuts on economic recovery, business growth, public health preparedness. The sequester, as a result of the Budget Control Act of 2011, has negative impacts on various sectors including defense, education, housing, and veterans affairs. It weakens public health preparedness, reduces resources for schools and colleges, compromises federal oversight, hinders scientific discovery, erodes infrastructure, and threatens emergency response capabilities globally. The sequester also hinders economic recovery, with potential GDP growth if eliminated. The sequester negatively impacts various sectors, weakening public health, education, and infrastructure. Relief from the sequester could boost GDP growth and employment. A previous government shutdown in 2013 cost the economy jobs and delayed services. Immediate negotiations are needed to prevent another shutdown and fund vital services. Immediate negotiations are necessary to raise discretionary spending caps for defense and non-defense, eliminating the non-defense sequester and reducing the defense sequester. Sequester relief should occur regardless of offsetting deficit reduction agreements. Bipartisan, bicameral agreement reached on sequester relief. A bipartisan measure will be negotiated to increase discretionary spending limits for fiscal years 2016 and 2017, with provisions to reduce the deficit. Members will be appointed by leaders in the House and Senate for approval and consideration of the measure. The measure described in subsection (a) requires approval from appointed individuals under subsection (b)(2). If approved, it will be considered under specific procedures from the Budget Control Act of 2011, with date substitutions. SEC. 3. ALTERNATIVE ADJUSTMENT TO DISCRETIONARY SPENDING LIMITS FOR FISCAL YEAR 2016 AND 2017. If the measure described under section 2(a) is not enacted into law before October 1, 2015, the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 will be amended to adjust discretionary spending limits for fiscal years 2016 and 2017. This includes specific dollar amounts for security and nonsecurity spending categories. The Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 will be amended to remove the Office of Management and Budget's authority if the measure under section 2(a) is not enacted by October 1, 2015.
